THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

JANUARY 29, 1902.

No. 8.

THE RECEPTION AT THE MEDICAL SCHOOL.
jOPKINS students have always had a just cause of complaint in the lack
of personal intercourse between teacher and pupil at the University. For
a few hours each week they come in contact with each other in the class
room, where the instructor must always remember he is the instructor, and the
pupil must always remember he is talking to his teacher. Man to man they
never meet, and even the adviser system, which offers such bright prospects on
matriculation day, has descended with most of us to the formality of a signature.
The great influence which the faculty members, as men, could exert on the
students is entirely neglected except for a fortunate few. Though home students
of course do not feel this so much as those from out of town, the state of affairs
is noticed by all.
The faculty has made the first move in relieving this condition by inaugurating a series of informal meetings, at which graduate students, medical students and undergraduates have the opportunity of meeting each other and
The announcement of the
members of the faculty—also their wives.
first meeting, which was held Saturday night, produced some little mysterious wonder among the students as to what the "informal meeting"
meant. Consequently there were not as many undergraduates present as
might have been, though quite as many as could be expected for the
first meeting. A very large proportion of the medical students was present, and
almost all the faculty. The married members of the faculty generally brought
their wives.
Thus when President Remsen stepped on the platform in the hall of the
physiological building, he had to face a large and interesting audience. Outlining the purpose of this meeting, he stated that it was the first of a proposed
series to demonstrate the human side of the instructors to the students; to offer
a means of bringing the different classes of students together in personal intercourse, and to promote a closer fellow-feeling all around. That this aim was
appreciated by most of the audience was testified by the applause which greeted
Dr. Remsen as he stepped off the platform to make way for Professor Bloomfield, who gave a short account of his reproduction of the famous Kashmirian
Atharva Veda.
Dr. Remsen had made a particular request for informality, and after the
talk by Dr. Bloomfield, student and prof. mingled together much more than
they had done before. Refreshments were served, after which a chance was

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

given to sow the seed of that personal intercourse which President Remsen
said was the object of the meeting. The newness of the affair at Hopkins
was somewhat of a drawback to its complete success, but those of the fellows
who were lucky enough to meet the "big men" of the faculty, their wives, and
the co-eds of the medical school, thoroughly enjoyed the evening. The only
trouble was that not enough men had that pleasure—a state of affairs probably due to a combination of their own backwardness and too much formality
in the atmosphere. However, the affair was an excellent beginning of what
ought to be an excellent project, and if the students only attend future meetings with the proper spirit, and the formality is a bit reduced, there is no reason why the results from it can not be all that is desired. These meetings, if
kept informal, certainly ought to produce a better spirit here.

MUSICAL CLUBS AT FOREST GLEN.

t

HE Musical Clubs gave a concert at the National Park Seminary on Monday night, January 27. The men left on a private car by the Baltimore
and Ohio at a little after five o'clock, and arrived at Forest Glen, Md.,
at 7.30. Here a light supper was served, and then the men wandered reluctantly from the beautifully-decorated dining-room to the concert hall. Here
more than two hundred of the girls and their friends were assembled, and even
the worst music won applause. The Glee and Banjo Clubs vied for first place
in point of excellence, and their leaders should he congratulated. After a short
programme, refreshments were served, and the men made the best of their opportunities till the manager called time, and the Clubs were once more homeward
bound. This concert did much to get the Clubs in line for the Baltimore concert of February 14, which is always the crucial test of the year.

THE BALTIMORE CONCERT.

ZHE

Johns Hopkins Musical Clubs will give their most important concert
on the night of February 14, in Lehmann's Hall. This date was judged,
after much consideration, to be the best time to give the concert, as it will
not conflict with any of the various athletic games that are being arranged for
February. What the condition of the Clubs will be at that time is a matter of
speculation, as there is still some time before the event. Still, if rehearsals are
kept up and the men work as hard as they have been doing lately, there is little
doubt but that the concert will be unusually interesting and successful.
It is hoped that more of the student body will be present this year than
formerly, for heretofore the clubs have received most of their support from those
outside of the University. This obviously should not be so, for the musical
organizations are part of the college life, and should receive the same support
that is accorded to athletics. Especially should the clubs receive support this
year from the whole student body; for, in giving the Athletic Association the
hundred dollars to help found a training table last year, the clubs left them-

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

selves in a bankrupt condition. In order to help the organization to meet the
heavy expenses that are necessary to maintain it, the faculty, graduate students,
and under.graduates are urged to attend this concert. If more interest were only
shown by the University in this annual concert, the clubs could each year
materially aid the various athletic enterprises.
In order that each member of the University may have an opportunity to
purchase a ticket, the faculty and various departments and classes will be so
divided amongst those having this matter in charge, that no one this year will
be able to say that he was not approached on this subject, and so was not present at the concert. If all the athletes and others would co-operate with the
members of the musical clubs, a successful concert would be assured, and the
high standard of previous years maintained.

ANOTHER APPROPRIATION.
T the last meeting of the "1901 Hullabaloo" board, held last week at the
home of the editor-in-chief, Mr. John G. Machen, affairs were finally
settled. Mr. Harry S. Byrne, the business manager of the book, re
ported a successful sale which netted a surplus of over forty dollars. The board
was much pleased with the administration of Mr. Byrne, and voted him a resolution of thanks and congratulations. Mr. Machen and Mr. Byrne were appointed a committee of two to deliver the money to the treasurer of that organization which might make best use of it. The appropriation will probably be
devoted to athletics, very likely to increase the bank account of the "field"
fund. On behalf of the student body the NEWS-LETTER begs to thank the
Hullabaloo Board for their generosity.

TWO LIBRARY NOTES.
CENTURY of thousands is now the official catalogue number of books
in the Hopkins library. The library assistant made out the card for the
100,000th book last week, though the number in the collection really
consists of some three or four thousand more which have not yet been catalogued. These include the gifts of the late Prof. Herbert B. Adams who left
to the University his complete library, which is still in a somewhat disordered
state. The growth of the library has been fast, and each year has seen added
to its shelves ancient and modern documents of value and interest. The NEWSLETTER hopes to publish in a near issue the story of this growth as told by one
of the gentlemen connected with the library staff since the beginning of the
University.
Another note of interest is the purchase of a new and handsome cabinet for
the royal works of Frederick the Great given to the University by the present
Emperor of Germany. The cabinet is a master piece of the wood carver's art,
and is a worthy case for the books it is to contain. The engravings of the seals
of the German Empire and of the University attract the attention of all who
have seen the cabinet.

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.
LECTURES OF A FORTNIGHT.

Z

HE second and third of Dr. Gilman's lectures on the general subject of
University Education were delivered on January 18th and 25th. Dr.
Gilman's lectures are attracting widespread attention, since, without
doubt, he is one of the greatest living authorities on the subject of advanced
education.
Saturday, the 18th, Dr. Gilman spoke upon "Original Research—Its
antiquity; Its modernity; Its opportunities, and its methods" He traced the
history of Original Research from ancient times to the present day, and said
that modern science owes a great debt to Lord Bacon, who was one of the first
great scientists of modern times. As regards the last quarter of the 19th
century, Dr. Gilman said that great advances in Original Research had been
made in this country. "And our own Johns Hopkins," he continued, "has
been in the front rank of all this vast work. In the beginning we were not
hampered as we are now, and our work then received the highest commendation
at home, and abroad." To those contemplating research work, Dr. Gilman
made some practical remarks, and said that necessary qualifications were: native
talent, good teachers, time, patience, knowledge of things, and imagination.
On last Saturday, Dr. Gilman took for his theme: "Scholarships, Fellowships, Burses, and Prizes." Ambition in its good and had sense was first
spoken of, Dr. Gilman explaining how it depended upon the motive of the
person. It was with pleasure, he said, that he had always found academic
circles governed by the proper kind of ambition: the desire to be honored for
spreading knowledge, and benefiting humanity. Fellowships, according to Dr.
Gilman, can be traced to the Younger Pliny, though properly they begin with
the dawn of the Universities in the 13th century. Continuing, Dr. Gilman gave
an account of the establishing of fellowships at Johns Hopkins, which was the
first American college to adopt the system. These scholarships brought to
Hopkins a body of students, of whom any university might be proud. The
subject of prizes was next taken up, Dr. Gilman explaining the difference
between them and fellowships. In closing, Dr. Gilman made a number of
valuable suggestions regarding the founding of scholarships.
Professor Richard G. Moulton, director of the department of English at the
University of Chicago, is delivering a course of six lectures on the general subject of "Ancient Tragedies for English Audiences." Professor Moulton is a
fascinating speaker, and the large crowds attending the lectures have the
Greek tragedies presented to them in an intensely interesting manner.
Under the auspices of the Baltimore branch of the Archwological Society
of America, of which Dr. Kirby F. Smith is secretary, Miss Harriet A. Boyd of
Smith College delivered an illustrated lecture on the afternoon of the 17th in
McCoy Hall. Her subject was "American Excavations in Crete, 1901." Miss
Boyd gave an account of the work done by the archaeologists in the East, and
showed many interesting views of the country, and of the discoveries made there
during the past year.

WHEN THE GAME WAS ENDED.
g staggered off the field into the arms of his friends with an exhausted,
though glorious feeling. This was the greatest day of his life. From
now on he was one of the heroes of Hopkins. How short a time ago it
was, that he seemed to have no chance for the varsity, though all along he felt
that all he. needed was a trial chance, that the other man's reputation of last year
was all that stood between him and the coveted place on the team. None of
the scrubs worked harder than he, but there did not seem to be any likelihood
of his getting into a game. How kind fate had been to him! Three days before
the big game, the one that would decide the championship, the varsity man had
wrenched his shoulder, so that the scrub had been given the place. The shouts
of the multitude told what use he had made of the opportunity. It was his
clever stroke that had shot the deciding goal, and the University's victory was
due to him. When there seemed to be no hope he had snatched victory from
the hands of defeat.
As cheer after cheer came over the field it was like the sound of heavenly
music. He saw some one coming with a sweater blazing with a golden "H,"
and stretching forth his
"Say, Freshman, come out of that trance, and get into this cheer."

QUI FILE?
"Quelle est eette etoile qui file,
Qzti file, file, et disparait?"
—thIRANGER.

Who is that whose star is falling?
Who is that whose prestige wanes?
Wont to hear all men him calling,
Now in vain his scepter claims.
'Tis the man we held in power,
Once his name to us was all,
Now his sand has passed the hour,
Great was his fame and great his fall.
Freshmen, who have had no fear,
Juniors, who have rushed the cane,
Will you, in the coming year,
Seniors, hold the palm again?
Be not haughty, curb your glory,
Defeat and Pride go hand in hand.
In college, 'tis the same old story,
You'll find no winner in the band.

MISTAKE was made in our Athletic columns last issue, which we desire
to rectify. In the report of the meeting of the Maryland Intercollegiate
Association it was stated that a "protest was registered against the Hopkins, on account of their playing graduates on their various athletic teams."
The writer of the article was misinformed as to the meeting, as absolutely no
protest was registered against Hopkins for any account whatever. At the meet
ing held on January 18, a discussion of the condition of the Association and
its place in Maryland athletics resulted in a unanimous decision to keep up the
Association. We deplore the impression which the article produced on the
student body.
HOUGH one vacant position on the NEws-LETTER has been filled by the
election of a junior to the staff, in a few weeks one or two more vacancies
will occur, which in all probability will be filled from the freshman class.
Already a cheering amount of work has been done by contestants from the class
of 1904 on all variations of literary lines. The work on the whole has been
satisfactory, and the contestants should not feel discouraged at not seeing their
contributions in print, as many things besides literary excellence must be taken
into consideration in posting up an issue. Every man who is trying for a position should keep up working, and work heartily. In a discrimination between
two equally good men, it is generally the "early bird catches the worm."

t

THE NEWS—LETTER.

7

HE Feed and Reunion which is going to be held on Friday of this week
promises to be one of the best ever held here. As announced in the last
issue of the NEWS LETTER, the feed is the only general student meeting
held during the year, and for that reason it is generally well supported by everybody. The program, which is given on another page of this issue, includes
talks by President Remsen and several members of the faculty, so that this will
be the first time that Dr. Remsen addresses the students in his new capacity.
To the older men we need say nothing about the attractions offered at these affairs, but we do want to impress on the freshmen the urgency of their attending en masse. The committee is also desirous of having present all Alumni
who can possibly attend, and the medical student or the grinding grad who can
spare an evening to the pleasures of life will be doubly welcomed.

t

O

N January 10th, Mr. Frank Moss, who was prosecuting attorney for the
famous Lexow Committee, delivered a lecture before the students of Lehigh University on ''Morality and Politics." He told of his share in the
investigation of political corruption in New York, and described graphically
some of the raids on the "policy shops" which used to thrive under police protection. He gave examples from his personal knowledge of open dishonesty
among city officials, and of the co-operation of respected citizens of New York.
Such a talk, delivered by an able man like Mr. Moss, thoroughly conversant with his ground, could not fail to attract and benefit any American student,
who looks forward to his personal responsibility in the body politic. If these
men of affairs were more often invited to the University, the five o'clock lectures
would become vastly more popular with the under-graduates, and would be to
them a good training for the part they are to play in the vital affairs of government and citizenship.

URING the last foot ball season the Hullabaloo yell was found to be not
as serviceable as some shorter yells which were adopted. As a rule
these yells were "benevolently assimilated" for the occasion from some
of our intercollegiate friends, and for that reason were only temporary. The
contrast between our own Hullabaloo and those shorter war cries was too evident' to need comment, and shows the immense superiority of a hard monosyllabic cry over a long one like the Hullabaloo. The Hullabaloo is a beautiful yell, but its beauty is greater than its practical use, and it ought, therefore,
be supplemented by some other shorter and more concise cry. The NEWSLETTER would like to receive from the student body or from Alumni original
yells, whose use shall be mainly for athletics, and which will "carry" across
the athletic field with more effect than the Hullabaloo. Monosyllables should
be employed in making a new yell.

111% R. JACOB H. HOLLANDER and Dr. G. E. Barnett, of the department of
Economics, will spend Thursday and Friday of this week in New York,
where they expect to attend the meeting of the Jewish Historical Association, of which Dr. Cyrus Adler, formerly of this University and now at the
the Smithsonian Institute, is President. Dr. Barnett will read a paper before
the Society.
Mr. R. H. Wright, of the Historical Department, is at present acting as
substitute in the place of Professor Ebaugh of the Baltimore City College. The
latter has accepted a position as instructor of mathematics in one of the New
York schools.
Last Friday night the Historical and Political Science Association held an
informal celebration in the historical library to commemorate the 472nd meeting
of the organization. The principal paper was read by Prof. Ramage of the
University of the South. On Friday, February 21 , the Association will hold a
re-union, to which all the old Hopkins members will be invited. Dr. J. Martin
Vincent has charge of the arrangements. On the 500th anniversary of the
Association, a large celebration is to be held.
A movement is on foot at the University of Maryland to form a club among
the Hopkins men who are studying there. We have a large representation
among the future lawyers, and the idea seems a good one.
The Hopkins Alumni banquet will be held on the night of February 22 at
the Music Hall. A large number of out of town Hopkinsonians will be here on
account of the celebration at that time, and the occasion promises to eclipse all
others held in former years.
Mr. George Cator, who was awarded a university scholarship by the board
of university studies, has waived the emolument. His action has been approved
by the board.
Within the next few days, a picture of the class of 1901 will grace one of
the corridors of McCoy Hall.
At a meeting of the Junior Class last week, Mr. Mr. H. K. Tootle was
elected toastmaster for the annual class banquet which will be held about
February 11. Tootle made such a decided hit in that capacity last year that
his election was unanimous.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

9

Mr. Roy Williams was elected captain of the Junior Track Team. Williams
comes from Lehigh, where he gained distinction for himself as a runner. He
has turned out regularly with the Hopkins Squad this season, and is expected
to show himself in the coming B. A. C. and J. H. U. games.
Fred C. Blanck was elected anchor-man on the Junior Tug-of-War Team,
which will pull against the Freshmen at the athletic feed on January 31.
The Junior Class decided unfavorably upon the question of supporting the
Seniors in holding a senior promenade; and as not enough men could be gotten
from a single class to fill McCoy Hall, the idea has been abandoned.
The Freshman Class has elected Strohbar supervisor of class athletics in
general, and Branham captain of the class track team.
The written challenge sent by the Freshmen to the Juniors regarding the
relay race, which came off last Saturday, was a rather officious proceeding for
such verdant youths. It signifies that they are at last beginning to regain
confidence in themselves after the troublous times of the past.
The Freshmen deserve congratulation for being the first class for several
years past which has enforced the law regarding the wearing of class numerals.
The Juniors took action in the matter early in the year, but the Freshmen were
the first to appear with their numerals on their jerseys.
The Juniors have not yet succeeded in persuading the Dean that it will be
highly beneficial for them to take a day off and attend a Session of Congress in
a body- Strange to relate, the Dean does not think that the Juniors derive the
benefits for which they endure a tiresome journey to distant Washington. Such
a thirst for knowledge should certainly be quenched, by the Dean's consent.
The piteous appeals and heart-rending cries which issue from McCoy Hall
almost every day do not mean that murder is being done or that the place is
afire. The unoffending Freshmen are preparing for the oratorical contest.
Hopkins students may be pleased to know that Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler,
recently elected president of Columbia University, is a nephew of Mr. Nicholas
Murray, the Librarian of the Hopkins. Dr. Butler has frequently been to Baltimore to visit Mr. Murray, and has been entertained at the University Club.
Since the curtains have been placed on the cage windows, it is perfectly
safe to bring ladies to the gym. However, some of our fair visitors may object
to not seeing so much of the Hopkins boys as formerly.
The number of Freshmen trying for a place in their oratorical contest has
been narrowed down to five—Licking, Rosenheim, Shapiro, Hutnerichouse and
Foster. Diligent practice was begun on Monday, under the direction of Dr.
Guy Carleton Lee. About a week before the event, the number of speakers
will be reduced to three, who will contest for the gold medal offered by Dr.
Lee.

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

At the annual meeting and banquet of the Yale Alumni Association
of Baltimore, held on the night of the 18th, Dr. Bernard C. Steiner was
chosen president for the coming year, and Dr. Wm. H. Welch was
appointed a member of the executive committee to serve for three years. Presi
dent Ira Remsen responded to the toast "Johns Hopkins." Extempore speeches
were made by Dr. Steiner and Dr. Welch.
The admirers of Dr. Guy Carleton Lee will be gratified to learn that his
book, "Historical Jurisprudence" is being translated into both the German and
Dutch languages.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
(
1pROF, HAUPT addressed the Graduate Students' Bible Class last Satur-

day morning on "The Song of Songs." His very helpful discussion
was much appreciated by those present. Prof. Haupt is soon to publish in The Journal of Bzblzcal Literature, an article giving new renderings, and
showing the correct order of "The Song of Songs."
The attention of all students interested in Bible study is called to the
excellent course now being offered under Prof. Haupt's direction, by Dr. Foote,
meeting Thursdays at 5 P. M. Dr. Foote is a very able literary and Biblical
scholar and Hopkins students should not allow his efforts in their behalf to be
enjoyed by outsiders alone.
The Fourth Student Volunteer Convention will be held in Toronto, Canada,
February 26—March 2. It promises to he the largest gathering of students
ever held, as 2,500 college men are expected to attend. The citizens of Toronto
are to entertain them all for the week of the conference. These conventions are
international, and are held every four years. Last time Hopkins sent one
delegate; this year the association expects to have three representatives. The
Executive Council has voted to pay the expenses of one delegate, and a collection is in progress among the members of the Association to defray the expenses
of another. Contributions may be handed to any officer of the Association.
The General Secretary will also attend, as will Mr. C. W. Young, of the Medical School, president of the Baltimore Student Volunteer Band.

January 9.
January 10. As a general rule, gentlemen, it is best not to put prussic
acid in your mouth.
January 11. In writing formal invitations, it is usually the thing to use
paper of a delicate lilac hue, and, though not absolutely necessary, it is most
excellent to have in them in lingering perfume of Roger & Gallait's cologne.
Musk and tobacco are hardly good form.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

January 12. These stones, gentlemen, are not the original diamonds;
those are in various other places. Therefore, in playing with them after lecture, it will hardly be profitable to slip them adroitly up your sleeves.
January 13. Just make a noise. Don't care how you make it. Roar like
the bull of Bashan; shriek like a woman at a bargain-counter; howl like those
in the dungeons of the damned; only make a noise.
January 16. When people played cards in the olden times, they used one
single little candle; but in these days of modern lighting, when people play
cards, they have half a dozen acetylene lamps on the table; on the mantelpiece are whole rows of candelabra; around the walls are countless gas jets; in
the hand of each man is a lighted bicycle lamp; and, suspended from the ceiling
are a dozen arc lights.
January 17. It is perfectly simple how, when the cat falls, it lights on its
feet: for, when beginning to fall, it sticks its tail between its teeth and chews it.
This naturally causes the tail to fly back to the position of equilibrium, and
thus a rotary motion being established, the cat is enabled to light on its feet.

SWEET STOLEN FRUIT.
Hours in the Library! Glad hours we loved!
Chair tilted back into some cozy nook,
By thoughts of tasks neglected all unmoved,
Dead to the world, living within a book;
The afternoons we left our work undone,
Left apparatus safely stowed away,
Left note-book closed, abandoned work for fun,
And in the Common Room loafed out the day;
The mornings we were looking for a quiz,
And therefore cut the class, and stole away,
And strolled down town and saw Man as He is,
Man—ignorant of quizzes—work and play;
Years after we shall think on these and smile,
Cast off our cares, again be boys awhile.
—P. W. '02.

A story is going the rounds of the medical school which very strongly illustrates Lord Chesterfield's words "clothes makes the man." A certain student in the first year, who is inclined ty corpulency, went down town to purchase a dissecting jacket at a local furZishing store. After trying on all the
white jackets in stock and finding none to suit, the student asked to see a colored jacket with small ornamentations in its design. A size 46 fitted him.
"I'll take this," he said to the clerk. The clerk looked up astonished, and replied very seriously, "But, my dear sir, you can't go behind the bar with that
jacket."

12

THE NEWS—LETTER.

ATHLETIC NOTES.
T was announced last week that our lacrosse team would not play the Cres•
cent Athletic Club this year. The reason for giving up such a "fixture"
as this game is on account of the lacrosse management being unable to
arrange a date with the Brooklyn team. At present the schedule is:
April 5, University of Pennsylvania, at Philadelphia.
April 19, Harvard, at Baltimore
April 26, Lehigh, at South Bethlehem. Championship game.
May 10, Swarthmore, at Baltimore. Championship game.
Manager Slemons attempted to arrange a game with the Crescents for April
12, but was unable to do so on account of conflicting dates. May 3rd was not
practicable, as it would be poor policy to put such a team in between the two
championship games. These dates will probably be filled by Columbia, Stevens, or C. C. N. V.

3

At a meeting of the track and field team held a short time ago, Mr. Murk land was chosen assistant manager. The management of the team is at present
busily engaged in arranging to enter men into the Baltimore Athletic Club and
the Georgetown games. Preparations are also being made for an indoor meet,
to he held in the Fifth Regiment Armory, during February.
A letter has been received by Manager Slemons from the University of
Toronto Lacrosse Club, asking for a game with our team during the last of
May. Owing to the nearness of the final examinations, however, the offer for
a game had to be declined.
The last few Saturdays have been record-breakers in the point of attendance at lacrosse practice. Over thirty men, or about twenty per cent. of the
whole under-graduate body, has been out each Saturday.
George Knapp, an old '99 man, who won all kinds of laurels for Hopkins,
was with us several days last week. His first appearance brought forth a
hearty "Gee hee, Gee-ha!" Pity we haven't a few more Knapps.
There was some talk last week of having as one of the features of last Saturday's athletic contest a relay race between the lacrosse and the track teams.
Captain Schmeisser, however, was probably fearful of the result, and decided
not to push matters. With a liberal handicap the lacrosse men might have
made things interesting for the sprinters.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

13

RESIGNATION OF CAPT. HOFFMAN.
T a joint meeting of the Track and Field Teams, held last Wednesday
afternoon, Mr. W. E. Hoffman, 1902, tendered his resignation as captain of the Track Team on account of press of other work. His resignation was accepted with a vote of thanks for his excellent services. Mr. J. T.
England was then unanimously elected as Mr. Hoffman's successor, and his
past record for executive ability as well as speed on the track will, no doubt,
enable him to prove a worthy official.
Just before the adjournment of the meeting Mr. Mackdermott made a short
speech, complimenting Mr. Hoffman on his splendid work in behalf of athletics,
and his unselfish and earnest efforts in making the track team what it has been
for the past year. He further stated that the team was in great need of fast men
this year, and urged that each man put his best foot foremost to keep up the
high standard which Hopkins has recently attained in this branch of athletics.
It is hoped that this request will be generously responded to, and that we
shall not have the humiliation of seeing one of our star teams fall below the
notch this year.

4

NEXT FRIDAY EVENING.
'/HE annual athletic feed and reunion will be held in the Gymnasium next
Friday evening, exercises beginning at 8 o'clock sharp.
These feeds have always been numbered among the most successful
affairs which the Hopkins has instituted, and from the vague accounts which
Dame Rumor has recently spread, this year's promises to eclipse anything of
the kind ever seen at the University.
The committee, of which Mr. J. G. Campbell is chairman, have been particularly strenuous in their efforts to make this event enjoyable to all who may
attend, and the programme which they have arranged, the details of which are
as yet unknown, promises to be exciting in every particular. The time-honored
custom of awarding the athletic "H's" to the members of the winning teams
will be observed as usual; and all those who have worked so patiently and earnestly in behalf of the Hopkins Athletics will receive the just reward of their
efforts. President Remsen and other prominent members of the faculty will be
present, and will deliver short addresses apropos to the occasion.
During the intervals several attractive selections will be rendered by members of the musical clubs, and Mr. Harry Wiel, of the Medical School, who is
known to be something of a pianist as well as a humorist, will do a piano
stunt. Whipple, assisted by others, has promised to give a startling exhibition in gymnastics, which is expected to be unique in itself.
Upon adjournment to the cage, an entirely new departure in the line of
events will be observed, as every feature in this part of the programme is
entirely original. The obstacle race promises to be quite amusing, while a tug
of war will once more test the strong rivalry existing between Freshman and

i.;

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Junior classes. A game of football, as it was played at Rugby, occupies a
corner on the list of "Stunts." These features are but "E pluribus paucum"
of the series which is to be offered, after which an abundant store of good things
to eat will be served.
These glorious occasions have always been fully attended by the student
body, alumni, as well as others, and it is hoped that a still greater number will
be present this year. It is particularly advised that all those who think there
is no college life at Hopkins will come and be astonished. The admission is
fifty cents.

JOINT INDOOR MEET.
HE first of a series of indoor games which are to be held under the
auspices of the General Athletic Association during the present winter
and the coming spring, was run off last Saturday afternoon in the Cage,
and proved a "howling" success. During the morning the committee in charge
had busied themselves, and when the games were called at three o'clock the
walls of the cage were gaudily decorated with class and University flags and
with the championship banners won by the football, baseball, track and field,
and lacrosse teams. Across the length of the gallery recently erected at the
west end of the cage was a long black and blue streamer which added to the
spirit of the occasion. From the windows of the gymnasium the wire screens
had been removed and a line of chairs put along the whole length. Both the
gallery and the gymnasium were filled with under-graduate and graduate students, former graduates and the lady friends of the various members of the
University, everyone cheering their favorites on to victory.
In every sense the meet was a success, and much honor is due to Physical
Director Mackdermott, who originated the scheme of"cage meets," to Captain
England and Manager Pearre of the track and field team, and Captain Schmeisser
of the lacrosse team, who ably assisted Mr. Mackdermott. The editors of the
NEWS-LETTER sincerely hope that the success of the initial meet will be sufficiently encouraging to those who had charge to arrange the next set of games for
a date in the near future.
The programme was started with a 35-yard dash across the cage, which,
owing to the large number of entries, had to be run off in five heats. The
entries and results for this and the other events follow:
First Heat—Won by Blanck; H. P. Straus, second. The other entries
were: Messrs. E. P. Bernheim, Sayler, and Branham.
Second Heat—E. Schmeisser, first; Abercrombie, second. Also ran, Bryan,
Bird, Custis and Putts.
Third Heat—R. C. Hoffman, Jr., first; Williams, second. Also ran, Porter, Rosenheim, LeCron and Emig.
Fourth Heat— Weedon, first; Riggs, second. Also ran, Hopper, Nelson,
Kohn and England.
Fifth Heat—Lindsay won; Riley second. Licking, Numsen, and Brem
also ran.

'OC

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

Semifinals—First heat: Abercrombie won; Blanck, second.
Second Heat—Weedon, first; Riggs, second.
Final—Abercrombie, first, Weedon, second.
The interclass relay race was the signal for an outburst of enthusiasm on
the parts of the junior and freshmen adherents, and was one of the most interesting events of the day. It was easily won by the upper classmen, but had it
not been 'for the unfortunate fall of Kohn, of the freshmen team, which proved
the most serious handicap for the lower classmen to overcome, it would have
been a nip-and-tuck race. Those who ran were : Juniors—E. Schmeisser,
Custis, R. C. Hoffman, Jr., and Williams. Freshmen—Kohn, Emig, Branham and Rosenheim.
Stone got first place in the 16-pound shotput, with Blanck a close second.
The other entries were: Messrs. Lawson, Rosenfeld, Whipple, Scholl, Sayler,
and Yearley. Stone's work in this event was great, and he showed much improvement in form over last year. He should do many things for his alma
mater this year.
Four forty yard run—J. T. England, scratch; Hoffman, Numsen, Nelson,
Lindsay, Joseph Smith and Licking. The handicap limit was 20 yards. England won, with Smith second.
The lacrosse game was the next event, and was a signal for another outburst of enthusiasm. The team was divided into halves, and the attack was
pitted against the defense. Those who were in the contest were:
No. 1—Briscoe, E Schmeisser, Sayler, Abercrombie, E. P. Bernheim, and
Putts.
No. 2—W. C. Schmeisser, H. P. Straus, Custis (Iglehart), Bird, Bryan,
and B. Bernheim.
The game resulted in a score of 7 to 7.
The running high jump was won by William S. Weedon, with George B.
Scholl second. Brem also jumped.
The games were ended with a half-mile run. There were only three entries,
and E. Schmeisser easily got first place. Porter got second, with Rosenheim
third.
The officials were: George W. Knapp, referee; J Morfit Mullen, marshal;
Aubrey Pearre, clerk of the course; W. M. Mackdermott, starter; E. B. Beasley, G. D. Dulaney, R. C. Pagon, and Henry Iddins, judges; J. R. B. Branch,
scorer; L. M. Tough, assistant scorer, and J. C. Campbell, announcer.
Referee of lacrosse game, J. Bandel; goal umpires, B. B. Bandel and E. C.
Hatch.
Many of the contestants who competed in these games will represent the
Hopkins in the B. A. C. indoor meet at the Fifth Regiment Armory next Saturday and for the Georgetown meet in Washington during the last of February.

THE NEWS—LETTER.
MARYLAND INTERCOLLEGIATE LEAGUE.

HE adjourned meeting of the Maryland Intercollegiate Association was
held on Saturday, January 18, in the office of the President, Mr. James
A. Fechtig, Jr.
The games committee, composed of Professor Cain, of St. John's, chairman, William E. Hoffman, Jr., of Johns Hopkins, and Mr. Gilligan, of Western Maryland, was authorized to prepare a list of specific events and the order
of running off the same at the intercollegiate track-field championship games in
May. They were also authorized to arrange the baseball dates for the approaching season.
The harmony which prevailed between the delegates was particularly noticeable, as a discussion of athletic topics is always liable to produce friction
and to rend asunder a meeting into contesting factions.
The Maryland League is to be congratulated upon the stand it has taken
on the subject of pure athletics. Some five years ago nearly every college team
had some trace of professionalism, and even at the present day it has not en
tirely disappeared from our leading institutions; but the Maryland League has
shown the way and set the example to other colleges by eliminating from its
own members every trace of anything but pure college sport. Such an affair as
recently happened at Harvard in regard to the standing of Cutts and at Yale in
regard to Glass, is impossible under the rules of the Maryland League.

ANOTHER TALK WITH WALTER.
4 43 HOPE this razor don't pull, sir; I just sharpened it on the face of a
freshman, sir, and it ought to be in good condition. He is a nice boy,
sir; he says that he goes to bed at ten o'clock because he is on the track
team, sir. It's strange how a freshman takes to the track team, sir. One gentleman, sir, said that it was Mr. Mackdermott's persuasive powers of speech, sir.
"'Everybody must get on your marks,' he shouts.
"'Heavens,' says a freshman from the Eastern Shore, sir, 'el my family
got on to my marks, I'd have to do some studying.'
"After the freshman has been properly instructed by Mr. Mackdermott,
the captain, and the manager, sir, then Mr. Mackdermott yells 'Get set.'
"At that, sir, don't you know, sir, they all lifts their backs like a cat that
sees a strange dog. Then, sir, somebody falls over the line, and the rest laugh.
But you have to see it, sir, I can't tell you about it.
"Yes, there were great games in the cage on S urday, sir. Before the
games, the freshmen were covering everything in sight; but as yet they have
not covered themselves with glory. What were the games for, sir? Why, to
show the world some fast Hopkins boys!
"Thank you, sir, that's three you owe me for, sir. Call again, sir."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

JANUARY 29, 1902.

No. 8.

THE RECEPTION AT THE MEDICAL SCHOOL.
jOPKINS students have always had a just cause of complaint in the lack
of personal intercourse between teacher and pupil at the University. For
a few hours each week they come in contact with each other in the class
room, where the instructor must always remember he is the instructor, and the
pupil must always remember he is talking to his teacher. Man to man they
never meet, and even the adviser system, which offers such bright prospects on
matriculation day, has descended with most of us to the formality of a signature.
The great influence which the faculty members, as men, could exert on the
students is entirely neglected except for a fortunate few. Though home students
of course do not feel this so much as those from out of town, the state of affairs
is noticed by all.
The faculty has made the first move in relieving this condition by inaugurating a series of informal meetings, at which graduate students, medical students and undergraduates have the opportunity of meeting each other and
The announcement of the
members of the faculty—also their wives.
first meeting, which was held Saturday night, produced some little mysterious wonder among the students as to what the "informal meeting"
meant. Consequently there were not as many undergraduates present as
might have been, though quite as many as could be expected for the
first meeting. A very large proportion of the medical students was present, and
almost all the faculty. The married members of the faculty generally brought
their wives.
Thus when President Remsen stepped on the platform in the hall of the
physiological building, he had to face a large and interesting audience. Outlining the purpose of this meeting, he stated that it was the first of a proposed
series to demonstrate the human side of the instructors to the students; to offer
a means of bringing the different classes of students together in personal intercourse, and to promote a closer fellow-feeling all around. That this aim was
appreciated by most of the audience was testified by the applause which greeted
Dr. Remsen as he stepped off the platform to make way for Professor Bloomfield, who gave a short account of his reproduction of the famous Kashmirian
Atharva Veda.
Dr. Remsen had made a particular request for informality, and after the
talk by Dr. Bloomfield, student and prof. mingled together much more than
they had done before. Refreshments were served, after which a chance was

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

given to sow the seed of that personal intercourse which President Remsen
said was the object of the meeting. The newness of the affair at Hopkins
was somewhat of a drawback to its complete success, but those of the fellows
who were lucky enough to meet the "big men" of the faculty, their wives, and
the co-eds of the medical school, thoroughly enjoyed the evening. The only
trouble was that not enough men had that pleasure—a state of affairs probably due to a combination of their own backwardness and too much formality
in the atmosphere. However, the affair was an excellent beginning of what
ought to be an excellent project, and if the students only attend future meetings with the proper spirit, and the formality is a bit reduced, there is no reason why the results from it can not be all that is desired. These meetings, if
kept informal, certainly ought to produce a better spirit here.

MUSICAL CLUBS AT FOREST GLEN.

t

HE Musical Clubs gave a concert at the National Park Seminary on Monday night, January 27. The men left on a private car by the Baltimore
and Ohio at a little after five o'clock, and arrived at Forest Glen, Md.,
at 7.30. Here a light supper was served, and then the men wandered reluctantly from the beautifully-decorated dining-room to the concert hall. Here
more than two hundred of the girls and their friends were assembled, and even
the worst music won applause. The Glee and Banjo Clubs vied for first place
in point of excellence, and their leaders should he congratulated. After a short
programme, refreshments were served, and the men made the best of their opportunities till the manager called time, and the Clubs were once more homeward
bound. This concert did much to get the Clubs in line for the Baltimore concert of February 14, which is always the crucial test of the year.

THE BALTIMORE CONCERT.

ZHE

Johns Hopkins Musical Clubs will give their most important concert
on the night of February 14, in Lehmann's Hall. This date was judged,
after much consideration, to be the best time to give the concert, as it will
not conflict with any of the various athletic games that are being arranged for
February. What the condition of the Clubs will be at that time is a matter of
speculation, as there is still some time before the event. Still, if rehearsals are
kept up and the men work as hard as they have been doing lately, there is little
doubt but that the concert will be unusually interesting and successful.
It is hoped that more of the student body will be present this year than
formerly, for heretofore the clubs have received most of their support from those
outside of the University. This obviously should not be so, for the musical
organizations are part of the college life, and should receive the same support
that is accorded to athletics. Especially should the clubs receive support this
year from the whole student body; for, in giving the Athletic Association the
hundred dollars to help found a training table last year, the clubs left them-

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

selves in a bankrupt condition. In order to help the organization to meet the
heavy expenses that are necessary to maintain it, the faculty, graduate students,
and under.graduates are urged to attend this concert. If more interest were only
shown by the University in this annual concert, the clubs could each year
materially aid the various athletic enterprises.
In order that each member of the University may have an opportunity to
purchase a ticket, the faculty and various departments and classes will be so
divided amongst those having this matter in charge, that no one this year will
be able to say that he was not approached on this subject, and so was not present at the concert. If all the athletes and others would co-operate with the
members of the musical clubs, a successful concert would be assured, and the
high standard of previous years maintained.

ANOTHER APPROPRIATION.
T the last meeting of the "1901 Hullabaloo" board, held last week at the
home of the editor-in-chief, Mr. John G. Machen, affairs were finally
settled. Mr. Harry S. Byrne, the business manager of the book, re
ported a successful sale which netted a surplus of over forty dollars. The board
was much pleased with the administration of Mr. Byrne, and voted him a resolution of thanks and congratulations. Mr. Machen and Mr. Byrne were appointed a committee of two to deliver the money to the treasurer of that organization which might make best use of it. The appropriation will probably be
devoted to athletics, very likely to increase the bank account of the "field"
fund. On behalf of the student body the NEWS-LETTER begs to thank the
Hullabaloo Board for their generosity.

TWO LIBRARY NOTES.
CENTURY of thousands is now the official catalogue number of books
in the Hopkins library. The library assistant made out the card for the
100,000th book last week, though the number in the collection really
consists of some three or four thousand more which have not yet been catalogued. These include the gifts of the late Prof. Herbert B. Adams who left
to the University his complete library, which is still in a somewhat disordered
state. The growth of the library has been fast, and each year has seen added
to its shelves ancient and modern documents of value and interest. The NEWSLETTER hopes to publish in a near issue the story of this growth as told by one
of the gentlemen connected with the library staff since the beginning of the
University.
Another note of interest is the purchase of a new and handsome cabinet for
the royal works of Frederick the Great given to the University by the present
Emperor of Germany. The cabinet is a master piece of the wood carver's art,
and is a worthy case for the books it is to contain. The engravings of the seals
of the German Empire and of the University attract the attention of all who
have seen the cabinet.

4

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.
LECTURES OF A FORTNIGHT.

Z

HE second and third of Dr. Gilman's lectures on the general subject of
University Education were delivered on January 18th and 25th. Dr.
Gilman's lectures are attracting widespread attention, since, without
doubt, he is one of the greatest living authorities on the subject of advanced
education.
Saturday, the 18th, Dr. Gilman spoke upon "Original Research—Its
antiquity; Its modernity; Its opportunities, and its methods" He traced the
history of Original Research from ancient times to the present day, and said
that modern science owes a great debt to Lord Bacon, who was one of the first
great scientists of modern times. As regards the last quarter of the 19th
century, Dr. Gilman said that great advances in Original Research had been
made in this country. "And our own Johns Hopkins," he continued, "has
been in the front rank of all this vast work. In the beginning we were not
hampered as we are now, and our work then received the highest commendation
at home, and abroad." To those contemplating research work, Dr. Gilman
made some practical remarks, and said that necessary qualifications were: native
talent, good teachers, time, patience, knowledge of things, and imagination.
On last Saturday, Dr. Gilman took for his theme: "Scholarships, Fellowships, Burses, and Prizes." Ambition in its good and had sense was first
spoken of, Dr. Gilman explaining how it depended upon the motive of the
person. It was with pleasure, he said, that he had always found academic
circles governed by the proper kind of ambition: the desire to be honored for
spreading knowledge, and benefiting humanity. Fellowships, according to Dr.
Gilman, can be traced to the Younger Pliny, though properly they begin with
the dawn of the Universities in the 13th century. Continuing, Dr. Gilman gave
an account of the establishing of fellowships at Johns Hopkins, which was the
first American college to adopt the system. These scholarships brought to
Hopkins a body of students, of whom any university might be proud. The
subject of prizes was next taken up, Dr. Gilman explaining the difference
between them and fellowships. In closing, Dr. Gilman made a number of
valuable suggestions regarding the founding of scholarships.
Professor Richard G. Moulton, director of the department of English at the
University of Chicago, is delivering a course of six lectures on the general subject of "Ancient Tragedies for English Audiences." Professor Moulton is a
fascinating speaker, and the large crowds attending the lectures have the
Greek tragedies presented to them in an intensely interesting manner.
Under the auspices of the Baltimore branch of the Archwological Society
of America, of which Dr. Kirby F. Smith is secretary, Miss Harriet A. Boyd of
Smith College delivered an illustrated lecture on the afternoon of the 17th in
McCoy Hall. Her subject was "American Excavations in Crete, 1901." Miss
Boyd gave an account of the work done by the archaeologists in the East, and
showed many interesting views of the country, and of the discoveries made there
during the past year.

WHEN THE GAME WAS ENDED.
g staggered off the field into the arms of his friends with an exhausted,
though glorious feeling. This was the greatest day of his life. From
now on he was one of the heroes of Hopkins. How short a time ago it
was, that he seemed to have no chance for the varsity, though all along he felt
that all he. needed was a trial chance, that the other man's reputation of last year
was all that stood between him and the coveted place on the team. None of
the scrubs worked harder than he, but there did not seem to be any likelihood
of his getting into a game. How kind fate had been to him! Three days before
the big game, the one that would decide the championship, the varsity man had
wrenched his shoulder, so that the scrub had been given the place. The shouts
of the multitude told what use he had made of the opportunity. It was his
clever stroke that had shot the deciding goal, and the University's victory was
due to him. When there seemed to be no hope he had snatched victory from
the hands of defeat.
As cheer after cheer came over the field it was like the sound of heavenly
music. He saw some one coming with a sweater blazing with a golden "H,"
and stretching forth his
"Say, Freshman, come out of that trance, and get into this cheer."

QUI FILE?
"Quelle est eette etoile qui file,
Qzti file, file, et disparait?"
—thIRANGER.

Who is that whose star is falling?
Who is that whose prestige wanes?
Wont to hear all men him calling,
Now in vain his scepter claims.
'Tis the man we held in power,
Once his name to us was all,
Now his sand has passed the hour,
Great was his fame and great his fall.
Freshmen, who have had no fear,
Juniors, who have rushed the cane,
Will you, in the coming year,
Seniors, hold the palm again?
Be not haughty, curb your glory,
Defeat and Pride go hand in hand.
In college, 'tis the same old story,
You'll find no winner in the band.

MISTAKE was made in our Athletic columns last issue, which we desire
to rectify. In the report of the meeting of the Maryland Intercollegiate
Association it was stated that a "protest was registered against the Hopkins, on account of their playing graduates on their various athletic teams."
The writer of the article was misinformed as to the meeting, as absolutely no
protest was registered against Hopkins for any account whatever. At the meet
ing held on January 18, a discussion of the condition of the Association and
its place in Maryland athletics resulted in a unanimous decision to keep up the
Association. We deplore the impression which the article produced on the
student body.
HOUGH one vacant position on the NEws-LETTER has been filled by the
election of a junior to the staff, in a few weeks one or two more vacancies
will occur, which in all probability will be filled from the freshman class.
Already a cheering amount of work has been done by contestants from the class
of 1904 on all variations of literary lines. The work on the whole has been
satisfactory, and the contestants should not feel discouraged at not seeing their
contributions in print, as many things besides literary excellence must be taken
into consideration in posting up an issue. Every man who is trying for a position should keep up working, and work heartily. In a discrimination between
two equally good men, it is generally the "early bird catches the worm."

t

THE NEWS—LETTER.

7

HE Feed and Reunion which is going to be held on Friday of this week
promises to be one of the best ever held here. As announced in the last
issue of the NEWS LETTER, the feed is the only general student meeting
held during the year, and for that reason it is generally well supported by everybody. The program, which is given on another page of this issue, includes
talks by President Remsen and several members of the faculty, so that this will
be the first time that Dr. Remsen addresses the students in his new capacity.
To the older men we need say nothing about the attractions offered at these affairs, but we do want to impress on the freshmen the urgency of their attending en masse. The committee is also desirous of having present all Alumni
who can possibly attend, and the medical student or the grinding grad who can
spare an evening to the pleasures of life will be doubly welcomed.

t

O

N January 10th, Mr. Frank Moss, who was prosecuting attorney for the
famous Lexow Committee, delivered a lecture before the students of Lehigh University on ''Morality and Politics." He told of his share in the
investigation of political corruption in New York, and described graphically
some of the raids on the "policy shops" which used to thrive under police protection. He gave examples from his personal knowledge of open dishonesty
among city officials, and of the co-operation of respected citizens of New York.
Such a talk, delivered by an able man like Mr. Moss, thoroughly conversant with his ground, could not fail to attract and benefit any American student,
who looks forward to his personal responsibility in the body politic. If these
men of affairs were more often invited to the University, the five o'clock lectures
would become vastly more popular with the under-graduates, and would be to
them a good training for the part they are to play in the vital affairs of government and citizenship.

URING the last foot ball season the Hullabaloo yell was found to be not
as serviceable as some shorter yells which were adopted. As a rule
these yells were "benevolently assimilated" for the occasion from some
of our intercollegiate friends, and for that reason were only temporary. The
contrast between our own Hullabaloo and those shorter war cries was too evident' to need comment, and shows the immense superiority of a hard monosyllabic cry over a long one like the Hullabaloo. The Hullabaloo is a beautiful yell, but its beauty is greater than its practical use, and it ought, therefore,
be supplemented by some other shorter and more concise cry. The NEWSLETTER would like to receive from the student body or from Alumni original
yells, whose use shall be mainly for athletics, and which will "carry" across
the athletic field with more effect than the Hullabaloo. Monosyllables should
be employed in making a new yell.

111% R. JACOB H. HOLLANDER and Dr. G. E. Barnett, of the department of
Economics, will spend Thursday and Friday of this week in New York,
where they expect to attend the meeting of the Jewish Historical Association, of which Dr. Cyrus Adler, formerly of this University and now at the
the Smithsonian Institute, is President. Dr. Barnett will read a paper before
the Society.
Mr. R. H. Wright, of the Historical Department, is at present acting as
substitute in the place of Professor Ebaugh of the Baltimore City College. The
latter has accepted a position as instructor of mathematics in one of the New
York schools.
Last Friday night the Historical and Political Science Association held an
informal celebration in the historical library to commemorate the 472nd meeting
of the organization. The principal paper was read by Prof. Ramage of the
University of the South. On Friday, February 21 , the Association will hold a
re-union, to which all the old Hopkins members will be invited. Dr. J. Martin
Vincent has charge of the arrangements. On the 500th anniversary of the
Association, a large celebration is to be held.
A movement is on foot at the University of Maryland to form a club among
the Hopkins men who are studying there. We have a large representation
among the future lawyers, and the idea seems a good one.
The Hopkins Alumni banquet will be held on the night of February 22 at
the Music Hall. A large number of out of town Hopkinsonians will be here on
account of the celebration at that time, and the occasion promises to eclipse all
others held in former years.
Mr. George Cator, who was awarded a university scholarship by the board
of university studies, has waived the emolument. His action has been approved
by the board.
Within the next few days, a picture of the class of 1901 will grace one of
the corridors of McCoy Hall.
At a meeting of the Junior Class last week, Mr. Mr. H. K. Tootle was
elected toastmaster for the annual class banquet which will be held about
February 11. Tootle made such a decided hit in that capacity last year that
his election was unanimous.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

9

Mr. Roy Williams was elected captain of the Junior Track Team. Williams
comes from Lehigh, where he gained distinction for himself as a runner. He
has turned out regularly with the Hopkins Squad this season, and is expected
to show himself in the coming B. A. C. and J. H. U. games.
Fred C. Blanck was elected anchor-man on the Junior Tug-of-War Team,
which will pull against the Freshmen at the athletic feed on January 31.
The Junior Class decided unfavorably upon the question of supporting the
Seniors in holding a senior promenade; and as not enough men could be gotten
from a single class to fill McCoy Hall, the idea has been abandoned.
The Freshman Class has elected Strohbar supervisor of class athletics in
general, and Branham captain of the class track team.
The written challenge sent by the Freshmen to the Juniors regarding the
relay race, which came off last Saturday, was a rather officious proceeding for
such verdant youths. It signifies that they are at last beginning to regain
confidence in themselves after the troublous times of the past.
The Freshmen deserve congratulation for being the first class for several
years past which has enforced the law regarding the wearing of class numerals.
The Juniors took action in the matter early in the year, but the Freshmen were
the first to appear with their numerals on their jerseys.
The Juniors have not yet succeeded in persuading the Dean that it will be
highly beneficial for them to take a day off and attend a Session of Congress in
a body- Strange to relate, the Dean does not think that the Juniors derive the
benefits for which they endure a tiresome journey to distant Washington. Such
a thirst for knowledge should certainly be quenched, by the Dean's consent.
The piteous appeals and heart-rending cries which issue from McCoy Hall
almost every day do not mean that murder is being done or that the place is
afire. The unoffending Freshmen are preparing for the oratorical contest.
Hopkins students may be pleased to know that Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler,
recently elected president of Columbia University, is a nephew of Mr. Nicholas
Murray, the Librarian of the Hopkins. Dr. Butler has frequently been to Baltimore to visit Mr. Murray, and has been entertained at the University Club.
Since the curtains have been placed on the cage windows, it is perfectly
safe to bring ladies to the gym. However, some of our fair visitors may object
to not seeing so much of the Hopkins boys as formerly.
The number of Freshmen trying for a place in their oratorical contest has
been narrowed down to five—Licking, Rosenheim, Shapiro, Hutnerichouse and
Foster. Diligent practice was begun on Monday, under the direction of Dr.
Guy Carleton Lee. About a week before the event, the number of speakers
will be reduced to three, who will contest for the gold medal offered by Dr.
Lee.

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

At the annual meeting and banquet of the Yale Alumni Association
of Baltimore, held on the night of the 18th, Dr. Bernard C. Steiner was
chosen president for the coming year, and Dr. Wm. H. Welch was
appointed a member of the executive committee to serve for three years. Presi
dent Ira Remsen responded to the toast "Johns Hopkins." Extempore speeches
were made by Dr. Steiner and Dr. Welch.
The admirers of Dr. Guy Carleton Lee will be gratified to learn that his
book, "Historical Jurisprudence" is being translated into both the German and
Dutch languages.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
(
1pROF, HAUPT addressed the Graduate Students' Bible Class last Satur-

day morning on "The Song of Songs." His very helpful discussion
was much appreciated by those present. Prof. Haupt is soon to publish in The Journal of Bzblzcal Literature, an article giving new renderings, and
showing the correct order of "The Song of Songs."
The attention of all students interested in Bible study is called to the
excellent course now being offered under Prof. Haupt's direction, by Dr. Foote,
meeting Thursdays at 5 P. M. Dr. Foote is a very able literary and Biblical
scholar and Hopkins students should not allow his efforts in their behalf to be
enjoyed by outsiders alone.
The Fourth Student Volunteer Convention will be held in Toronto, Canada,
February 26—March 2. It promises to he the largest gathering of students
ever held, as 2,500 college men are expected to attend. The citizens of Toronto
are to entertain them all for the week of the conference. These conventions are
international, and are held every four years. Last time Hopkins sent one
delegate; this year the association expects to have three representatives. The
Executive Council has voted to pay the expenses of one delegate, and a collection is in progress among the members of the Association to defray the expenses
of another. Contributions may be handed to any officer of the Association.
The General Secretary will also attend, as will Mr. C. W. Young, of the Medical School, president of the Baltimore Student Volunteer Band.

January 9.
January 10. As a general rule, gentlemen, it is best not to put prussic
acid in your mouth.
January 11. In writing formal invitations, it is usually the thing to use
paper of a delicate lilac hue, and, though not absolutely necessary, it is most
excellent to have in them in lingering perfume of Roger & Gallait's cologne.
Musk and tobacco are hardly good form.

January 12. These stones, gentlemen, are not the original diamonds;
those are in various other places. Therefore, in playing with them after lecture, it will hardly be profitable to slip them adroitly up your sleeves.
January 13. Just make a noise. Don't care how you make it. Roar like
the bull of Bashan; shriek like a woman at a bargain-counter; howl like those
in the dungeons of the damned; only make a noise.
January 16. When people played cards in the olden times, they used one
single little candle; but in these days of modern lighting, when people play
cards, they have half a dozen acetylene lamps on the table; on the mantelpiece are whole rows of candelabra; around the walls are countless gas jets; in
the hand of each man is a lighted bicycle lamp; and, suspended from the ceiling
are a dozen arc lights.
January 17. It is perfectly simple how, when the cat falls, it lights on its
feet: for, when beginning to fall, it sticks its tail between its teeth and chews it.
This naturally causes the tail to fly back to the position of equilibrium, and
thus a rotary motion being established, the cat is enabled to light on its feet.

SWEET STOLEN FRUIT.
Hours in the Library! Glad hours we loved!
Chair tilted back into some cozy nook,
By thoughts of tasks neglected all unmoved,
Dead to the world, living within a book;
The afternoons we left our work undone,
Left apparatus safely stowed away,
Left note-book closed, abandoned work for fun,
And in the Common Room loafed out the day;
The mornings we were looking for a quiz,
And therefore cut the class, and stole away,
And strolled down town and saw Man as He is,
Man—ignorant of quizzes—work and play;
Years after we shall think on these and smile,
Cast off our cares, again be boys awhile.
—P. W. '02.

A story is going the rounds of the medical school which very strongly illustrates Lord Chesterfield's words "clothes makes the man." A certain student in the first year, who is inclined ty corpulency, went down town to purchase a dissecting jacket at a local furZishing store. After trying on all the
white jackets in stock and finding none to suit, the student asked to see a colored jacket with small ornamentations in its design. A size 46 fitted him.
"I'll take this," he said to the clerk. The clerk looked up astonished, and replied very seriously, "But, my dear sir, you can't go behind the bar with that
jacket."

THE NEWS—LETTER.

ATHLETIC NOTES.
T was announced last week that our lacrosse team would not play the Cres•
cent Athletic Club this year. The reason for giving up such a "fixture"
as this game is on account of the lacrosse management being unable to
arrange a date with the Brooklyn team. At present the schedule is:
April 5, University of Pennsylvania, at Philadelphia.
April 19, Harvard, at Baltimore
April 26, Lehigh, at South Bethlehem. Championship game.
May 10, Swarthmore, at Baltimore. Championship game.
Manager Slemons attempted to arrange a game with the Crescents for April
12, but was unable to do so on account of conflicting dates. May 3rd was not
practicable, as it would be poor policy to put such a team in between the two
championship games. These dates will probably be filled by Columbia, Stevens, or C. C. N. V.

3

At a meeting of the track and field team held a short time ago, Mr. Murk land was chosen assistant manager. The management of the team is at present
busily engaged in arranging to enter men into the Baltimore Athletic Club and
the Georgetown games. Preparations are also being made for an indoor meet,
to he held in the Fifth Regiment Armory, during February.
A letter has been received by Manager Slemons from the University of
Toronto Lacrosse Club, asking for a game with our team during the last of
May. Owing to the nearness of the final examinations, however, the offer for
a game had to be declined.
The last few Saturdays have been record-breakers in the point of attendance at lacrosse practice. Over thirty men, or about twenty per cent. of the
whole under-graduate body, has been out each Saturday.
George Knapp, an old '99 man, who won all kinds of laurels for Hopkins,
was with us several days last week. His first appearance brought forth a
hearty "Gee hee, Gee-ha!" Pity we haven't a few more Knapps.
There was some talk last week of having as one of the features of last Saturday's athletic contest a relay race between the lacrosse and the track teams.
Captain Schmeisser, however, was probably fearful of the result, and decided
not to push matters. With a liberal handicap the lacrosse men might have
made things interesting for the sprinters.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

13

RESIGNATION OF CAPT. HOFFMAN.
T a joint meeting of the Track and Field Teams, held last Wednesday
afternoon, Mr. W. E. Hoffman, 1902, tendered his resignation as captain of the Track Team on account of press of other work. His resignation was accepted with a vote of thanks for his excellent services. Mr. J. T.
England was then unanimously elected as Mr. Hoffman's successor, and his
past record for executive ability as well as speed on the track will, no doubt,
enable him to prove a worthy official.
Just before the adjournment of the meeting Mr. Mackdermott made a short
speech, complimenting Mr. Hoffman on his splendid work in behalf of athletics,
and his unselfish and earnest efforts in making the track team what it has been
for the past year. He further stated that the team was in great need of fast men
this year, and urged that each man put his best foot foremost to keep up the
high standard which Hopkins has recently attained in this branch of athletics.
It is hoped that this request will be generously responded to, and that we
shall not have the humiliation of seeing one of our star teams fall below the
notch this year.

4

NEXT FRIDAY EVENING.
'/HE annual athletic feed and reunion will be held in the Gymnasium next
Friday evening, exercises beginning at 8 o'clock sharp.
These feeds have always been numbered among the most successful
affairs which the Hopkins has instituted, and from the vague accounts which
Dame Rumor has recently spread, this year's promises to eclipse anything of
the kind ever seen at the University.
The committee, of which Mr. J. G. Campbell is chairman, have been particularly strenuous in their efforts to make this event enjoyable to all who may
attend, and the programme which they have arranged, the details of which are
as yet unknown, promises to be exciting in every particular. The time-honored
custom of awarding the athletic "H's" to the members of the winning teams
will be observed as usual; and all those who have worked so patiently and earnestly in behalf of the Hopkins Athletics will receive the just reward of their
efforts. President Remsen and other prominent members of the faculty will be
present, and will deliver short addresses apropos to the occasion.
During the intervals several attractive selections will be rendered by members of the musical clubs, and Mr. Harry Wiel, of the Medical School, who is
known to be something of a pianist as well as a humorist, will do a piano
stunt. Whipple, assisted by others, has promised to give a startling exhibition in gymnastics, which is expected to be unique in itself.
Upon adjournment to the cage, an entirely new departure in the line of
events will be observed, as every feature in this part of the programme is
entirely original. The obstacle race promises to be quite amusing, while a tug
of war will once more test the strong rivalry existing between Freshman and

i.;

14

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Junior classes. A game of football, as it was played at Rugby, occupies a
corner on the list of "Stunts." These features are but "E pluribus paucum"
of the series which is to be offered, after which an abundant store of good things
to eat will be served.
These glorious occasions have always been fully attended by the student
body, alumni, as well as others, and it is hoped that a still greater number will
be present this year. It is particularly advised that all those who think there
is no college life at Hopkins will come and be astonished. The admission is
fifty cents.

JOINT INDOOR MEET.
HE first of a series of indoor games which are to be held under the
auspices of the General Athletic Association during the present winter
and the coming spring, was run off last Saturday afternoon in the Cage,
and proved a "howling" success. During the morning the committee in charge
had busied themselves, and when the games were called at three o'clock the
walls of the cage were gaudily decorated with class and University flags and
with the championship banners won by the football, baseball, track and field,
and lacrosse teams. Across the length of the gallery recently erected at the
west end of the cage was a long black and blue streamer which added to the
spirit of the occasion. From the windows of the gymnasium the wire screens
had been removed and a line of chairs put along the whole length. Both the
gallery and the gymnasium were filled with under-graduate and graduate students, former graduates and the lady friends of the various members of the
University, everyone cheering their favorites on to victory.
In every sense the meet was a success, and much honor is due to Physical
Director Mackdermott, who originated the scheme of"cage meets," to Captain
England and Manager Pearre of the track and field team, and Captain Schmeisser
of the lacrosse team, who ably assisted Mr. Mackdermott. The editors of the
NEWS-LETTER sincerely hope that the success of the initial meet will be sufficiently encouraging to those who had charge to arrange the next set of games for
a date in the near future.
The programme was started with a 35-yard dash across the cage, which,
owing to the large number of entries, had to be run off in five heats. The
entries and results for this and the other events follow:
First Heat—Won by Blanck; H. P. Straus, second. The other entries
were: Messrs. E. P. Bernheim, Sayler, and Branham.
Second Heat—E. Schmeisser, first; Abercrombie, second. Also ran, Bryan,
Bird, Custis and Putts.
Third Heat—R. C. Hoffman, Jr., first; Williams, second. Also ran, Porter, Rosenheim, LeCron and Emig.
Fourth Heat— Weedon, first; Riggs, second. Also ran, Hopper, Nelson,
Kohn and England.
Fifth Heat—Lindsay won; Riley second. Licking, Numsen, and Brem
also ran.

'OC

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

Semifinals—First heat: Abercrombie won; Blanck, second.
Second Heat—Weedon, first; Riggs, second.
Final—Abercrombie, first, Weedon, second.
The interclass relay race was the signal for an outburst of enthusiasm on
the parts of the junior and freshmen adherents, and was one of the most interesting events of the day. It was easily won by the upper classmen, but had it
not been 'for the unfortunate fall of Kohn, of the freshmen team, which proved
the most serious handicap for the lower classmen to overcome, it would have
been a nip-and-tuck race. Those who ran were : Juniors—E. Schmeisser,
Custis, R. C. Hoffman, Jr., and Williams. Freshmen—Kohn, Emig, Branham and Rosenheim.
Stone got first place in the 16-pound shotput, with Blanck a close second.
The other entries were: Messrs. Lawson, Rosenfeld, Whipple, Scholl, Sayler,
and Yearley. Stone's work in this event was great, and he showed much improvement in form over last year. He should do many things for his alma
mater this year.
Four forty yard run—J. T. England, scratch; Hoffman, Numsen, Nelson,
Lindsay, Joseph Smith and Licking. The handicap limit was 20 yards. England won, with Smith second.
The lacrosse game was the next event, and was a signal for another outburst of enthusiasm. The team was divided into halves, and the attack was
pitted against the defense. Those who were in the contest were:
No. 1—Briscoe, E Schmeisser, Sayler, Abercrombie, E. P. Bernheim, and
Putts.
No. 2—W. C. Schmeisser, H. P. Straus, Custis (Iglehart), Bird, Bryan,
and B. Bernheim.
The game resulted in a score of 7 to 7.
The running high jump was won by William S. Weedon, with George B.
Scholl second. Brem also jumped.
The games were ended with a half-mile run. There were only three entries,
and E. Schmeisser easily got first place. Porter got second, with Rosenheim
third.
The officials were: George W. Knapp, referee; J Morfit Mullen, marshal;
Aubrey Pearre, clerk of the course; W. M. Mackdermott, starter; E. B. Beasley, G. D. Dulaney, R. C. Pagon, and Henry Iddins, judges; J. R. B. Branch,
scorer; L. M. Tough, assistant scorer, and J. C. Campbell, announcer.
Referee of lacrosse game, J. Bandel; goal umpires, B. B. Bandel and E. C.
Hatch.
Many of the contestants who competed in these games will represent the
Hopkins in the B. A. C. indoor meet at the Fifth Regiment Armory next Saturday and for the Georgetown meet in Washington during the last of February.

THE NEWS—LETTER.
MARYLAND INTERCOLLEGIATE LEAGUE.

HE adjourned meeting of the Maryland Intercollegiate Association was
held on Saturday, January 18, in the office of the President, Mr. James
A. Fechtig, Jr.
The games committee, composed of Professor Cain, of St. John's, chairman, William E. Hoffman, Jr., of Johns Hopkins, and Mr. Gilligan, of Western Maryland, was authorized to prepare a list of specific events and the order
of running off the same at the intercollegiate track-field championship games in
May. They were also authorized to arrange the baseball dates for the approaching season.
The harmony which prevailed between the delegates was particularly noticeable, as a discussion of athletic topics is always liable to produce friction
and to rend asunder a meeting into contesting factions.
The Maryland League is to be congratulated upon the stand it has taken
on the subject of pure athletics. Some five years ago nearly every college team
had some trace of professionalism, and even at the present day it has not en
tirely disappeared from our leading institutions; but the Maryland League has
shown the way and set the example to other colleges by eliminating from its
own members every trace of anything but pure college sport. Such an affair as
recently happened at Harvard in regard to the standing of Cutts and at Yale in
regard to Glass, is impossible under the rules of the Maryland League.

ANOTHER TALK WITH WALTER.
4 43 HOPE this razor don't pull, sir; I just sharpened it on the face of a
freshman, sir, and it ought to be in good condition. He is a nice boy,
sir; he says that he goes to bed at ten o'clock because he is on the track
team, sir. It's strange how a freshman takes to the track team, sir. One gentleman, sir, said that it was Mr. Mackdermott's persuasive powers of speech, sir.
"'Everybody must get on your marks,' he shouts.
"'Heavens,' says a freshman from the Eastern Shore, sir, 'el my family
got on to my marks, I'd have to do some studying.'
"After the freshman has been properly instructed by Mr. Mackdermott,
the captain, and the manager, sir, then Mr. Mackdermott yells 'Get set.'
"At that, sir, don't you know, sir, they all lifts their backs like a cat that
sees a strange dog. Then, sir, somebody falls over the line, and the rest laugh.
But you have to see it, sir, I can't tell you about it.
"Yes, there were great games in the cage on S urday, sir. Before the
games, the freshmen were covering everything in sight; but as yet they have
not covered themselves with glory. What were the games for, sir? Why, to
show the world some fast Hopkins boys!
"Thank you, sir, that's three you owe me for, sir. Call again, sir."
